data.title: 12 Big-Screen Paranormal Investigators, Ranked by Their Ghost-Busting Success

data.text:
In honor of Amazonâs new series Truth Seekers, weâre rounding up our favorite embodiments of that good olâ scary-movie trope: ghost hunters! Technically all of these folks succeed because they all find ghosts (thatâs why thereâs no Scooby-Doo gang on this list), but some triumph more than others.

Just want to preface this list by saying weâre not necessarily ranking by how good the movie isâwe actually like and recommend most of these!âbut by how successful the investigators are: do they get rid of the ghost and/or ghosts? Do they survive? Do other people around them survive? Do they save the entire city of New York from a supernatural apocalypse? You get the idea.

12) Grave Encounters

Colin Minihan and Stuart Ortizâs 2011 film gets around the found-footage dilemma of âwhy are they filming every damn thing?â by making it about people who do that for a living: the crew of a ghost-hunting reality show. Led by the Zak Bagans-esque Lance Preston (Sean Rogerson), the group barricades themselves inside an abandoned psychiatric hospital with cameras galore, ostensibly to capture some evidence of paranormal goings-on (even though none of them are believers). But theyâre in for it when malevolent entities start making their presence felt, and the asylum itself seemingly manipulates time and space to keep everyone trapped in perpetual darkness. Thankfully, the spirits donât monkey around with anyoneâs battery life, so we get to see how the whole production spirals out of controlâand it doesnât end well for anyone, except the ghosts.

11) Terrified

Want to see a nightmare-inducing horror movie? Watch DemiÃ¡n Rugnaâs excellent 2017 release Terrified. Got a spooky situation in your house and need professional help? Maybe donât contact the paranormal enthusiasts in Terrified. While theyâre all highly respected, to the point of the Buenos Aires police allowing them free reign to do their thing, the elderly trioâJano (Norberto Gonzalo), Albreck (Elvira Onetto), and Rosentock (George L. Lewis)âisnât exactly a crack team in the field. Early in the movie, Albreck takes so long getting back to a petrified would-be client that heâs disappeared when she finally visits his house. Then, when it becomes clear his plight is tied to other weird occurrences in the areaâincluding a brutal murder by an apparently invisible assailantâthe group finally gets organized. Sort of.

First mistake: they separate immediately, posting up in neighboring houses thatâve all reported strange activity. Only Rosentock shows up with anything resembling high-tech equipment, not that gadgets would help much in this particular scenario. And they donât really have a plan other than âobserve and report,â which suggests that despite all their smarts, they donât understand how much danger theyâre putting themselves in. Itâs really not all that surprising when Terrifiedâs creatures emerge and start picking them off in variously gruesome ways, but holy hell is it scary.

10) The Innkeepers

Claire (Sara Paxton), the endearingly awkward protagonist of Ti Westâs 2011 The Innkeepers, isnât a professional ghost hunterâsheâs not even that into her job at historic hotel the Yankee Pedlar, a feeling enhanced by the fact that the place is about to shut down permanently. But what might otherwise be a dull routine of checking guests in and out and bringing them extra towels is spiced up by the fact that the hotel is said to be haunted, something Claireâs similarly bored co-worker, Luke (Pat Healy), has attempted to capitalize upon with his website, âReal Hauntings.â

Luke claims to have had genuine supernatural encounters at the Yankee Pedlar (conveniently, he didnât have his camera with him at the time), but Claire is determined to witness something herself, and capture it for Lukeâs site, on her last weekend working there. Armed with headphones and audio recording equipment that targets EVPs, she sets out to make contactâand though thereâs a certain amount of goofing off that goes on, her eventual journey into the hotelâs very creepy basement proves to be unwise. As The Innkeepers shows us, and another movie on this list further underlines (The Awakening, a few places down), itâs a very bad idea to mess around with ghosts if youâre at any risk of scaring yourself into a fatal asthma attack.

9) Insidious

In James Wanâs 2010 blockbuster, the Lambert family packs up and moves out of their new house after only living there a short whileâwouldnât you, if you thought your digs were haunted? Alas, they start having similar issues in their new new house. Enter paranormal investigators Tucker (Angus Sampson) and Specs (Leigh Whannell, who went on to direct this yearâs The Invisible Man). Theyâre dressed like the Pulp Fiction guys, and they bicker endlessly as they set up their equipment, which involves several cameras and other doohickeys so specialized Tucker is sure to announce that made them himself. These two characters invite some levity into whatâs otherwise a pretty tense movie, but the real MVP is the third member of their team: psychic investigator Elise Rainier (Lin Shaye), who instantly intuits that this isnât a typical haunted house situation, though there are evil spirits involved.

The scene with the gas mask, in which Specs scribbles down Eliseâs otherworldly whispers, is one of cinemaâs most terrifying sÃ©ances ever. But one of those creepy entities gets the better of Elise in the end, which is why Insidiousâ ghost-hunters rank so low on this list. That said, Elise made such an impression with fans that sheâs appeared in every Insidious film that followed (sheâll probably even pop up in that just-announced fifth Insidious film, timeline be damned). Thank goodness for flashbacks and prequels.

8-7) The Legend of Hell House and The Haunting

Richard Mathesonâs 1971 novel Hell House formed the basis for this 1973 John Hough film about ghost-huntersâtwo psychics, plus a guy with a ghost-neutralizing contraption who brings his wife along for funâwho are offered a princely sum to investigate the ghouls of Belasco House. The sprawling British estateâs reputation is pretty well summed up by its nickname, but as Roddy McDowallâs character dryly informs us, the deceased former owner of the home casts a shadow of evil thanks to his fondness for âdrug addiction, alcoholism, sadism, bestiality, mutilation, murder, vampirism, necrophilia, cannibalism, not to mention a gamut of sexual goodies.â The house is dripping with gothic atmosphere, deceptive spirits, and attack cats, and not everybody survives through act threeâbut the machine, which is never really explained but is sort of like a giant EMP that zaps away spiritsâends up making a convincing case in favor of techno-powered exorcisms.

Robert Wiseâs 1963 adaptation of Shirley Jacksonâs 1959 The Haunting of Hill House, titled simply The Haunting, actually got there first with a very similar tale of a haunted mansion thatâs targeted for paranormal investigation with tragic results. But unlike The Legend of Hell House, which ends with an inkling of hope that the ghosts have been purged, you get the sense that Hill House will always be haunted (unless youâre watching the ghastly 1999 remake, which serves up a smidge of closure enhanced by some very iffy CG effects).

6) 1408

Author Mike Enslin (John Cusack) has made a decent enough living writing âhauntedâ travel guides, though on all his research tripsâarmed with stuff like an infrared camera, an EMF reader, and his handheld recorderâheâs never actually encountered a ghost, or witnessed anything particularly spooky for that matter. Heâs grown so jaded and skeptical that heâs just going through the motions at this point…until he receives a mysterious tip about a New York City hotel and is intrigued enough to go check it out.

Mikael HÃ¥fstrÃ¶mâsÂ 2007 filmÂ 1408 is based on a Stephen King short story, and though the room Mike stays inâover the strenuous objections of the hospitality manager, played by Samuel L. Jacksonâis only the second most famous hotel room Kingâs ever written about, its malevolence and mind-fuckery capabilities actually give the Overlook Hotel a genuine run for the money. Mikeâs experiences somewhat mirrors those of the crew in Grave Encounters, though unlike those unfortunate would-be TV stars, Mike manages to squelch the evil at its source before making his own unfortunate exit off this mortal coil.

5) The Awakening

Florence (Rebecca Hall), a wealthy British woman grieving her soldier fiancÃ© who died in World War I, hopes to make contact with him from the beyondâbut instead makes a name for herself debunking fake mediums and disrupting contrived sÃ©ances. Pushed to the brink emotionally, she nonetheless agrees to investigate an alleged haunting at an all-boysâ boarding school, where a decades-old legend and a studentâs recent death have stirred up some bad PR (âYou must be the ghost lady,â the headmaster sighs with a mix of relief and resignation when she arrives).

Florence uses her equipment (the best the 1920s could provide, including a âMarconi magnetic field detectorâ) to quickly uncover the expected hoax, but soon realizes thereâs some deeper truth to the stories after allâand sheâll need to look within herself to confront the schoolâs all-too-real lingering souls. Director Nick Murphyâs chiller veers off the expected narrative path about midway through, and though the juryâs still out on The Awakeningâs ambiguous ending, the rest is helped along by some lovely cinematography and strong performances by Hall, Dominic West, Imelda Staunton, and Isaac âBran Starkâ Hempstead-Wright.

4) Poltergeist

About 40 minutes into this 1982 Tobe Hooper-Steven Spielberg classic, desperate dad Steve Freeling (Craig T. Nelson) seeks help from a trio of UC Irvine parapsychologists. These are people whose field he might have scoffed at under normal circumstances, but considering his young daughterâs been kidnapped into the spirit realm, heâs suddenly become far more open-minded. Setting the standard for paranormal-investigator characters in horror movies for decades to come, Drs. Martha Lesh (Beatrice Straight), Ryan Mitchell (Richard Lawson), and Marty Casey (Martin Casella) fill the suburban Freeling home with specialized equipment and settle in for an action-packed night thatâll blow all their previous research out of the water.

That first experience proves so harrowing (that skin-peeling scene gets me every time), the team calls in the big guns: psychic medium Tangina (Zelda Rubinstein). Her guidance proves incredibly valuableâshe helps Diane Freeling (JoBeth Williams) contact and rescue little Carol Anne (Heather OâRourke) from the other sideâthough her famous declaration of âThis house is cleanâ does end up proving a bit premature.

3) The Frighteners

Peter Jacksonâs first Hollywood venture (after finding success in New Zealand with movies like Bad Taste and Heavenly Creatures) remains one of the most unique ghost-hunter movies ever made. Frank Bannister (Michael J. Fox) has turned his talent for communicating with ghosts into a tidy little scam, getting his spectral pals to âhauntâ houses that heâll then be hired to exorcise.

Thatâs already a very clever premise, but things get even more complicated when a serial killerâs ghost starts claiming victims from beyond the graveâand Frank has to endure a couple of near-death experiences in order to stop him. No other movie on this list dares to push its storyline so far into fantasy, and in less capable hands (and with crappier effects; for 1996, The Frighteners is top-notch) it might not have worked so well. But who better to catch a ghost than a guy who can talk to ghostsâand will even turn into a ghost himself if the circumstances demand it?

2) The Conjuring

Another James Wan horror juggernaut, 2013’sThe Conjuring purports to tell the true story of the Perron family, who move into a rustic Rhode Island farmhouse filled with cast-off furniture and trinkets left by previous owners, along withâmuch to their horrorâa ferocious demonic presence. Whether or not this tale resembles real-life events is up to the viewer to judge; whatâs certain is that the paranormal investigators in the movie are based on actual people: Ed and Lorraine Warren, played by Patrick Wilson and Vera Farmiga.

Not only do they collect cursed objects for safekeeping in a creepy museum attached to their house, they give lectures on their past cases while selectively taking on new ones. Edâs the gadget guy, Lorraine uses her clairvoyant gifts to communicate with whateverâs skulking in the shadows, and they have assistants who step in to help them on big projectsâlike rigging the Perronâs home with cameras and other recording devices. They also have the resources to dig up historical information when they need it, which comes in handy when the property has a tragic past involving, for instance, a vengeful witch. To that end, they also have the Catholic Church on speed-dial, which helps when they need the go-ahead to perform an urgent exorcism. The Warrens are seasoned pros; they succeed because they have this ghost-hunting thing on lock. It seems pretty safe to assume the upcoming Conjuring 3 will continue their winning streak.

1) Ghostbusters

Obviously. They werenât the first to find a way to monetize their spirit-hunting skills, but only they had backpack-rigged proton packs, an upcycled Cadillac ambulance/hearse, a converted firehouse as their HQ, and even their own catchy-as-hell theme song. Plus they got real results, overcoming some serious EPA sabotage to defeat the towering threat of cross-dimensional beings with the power to summon giant marshmallow men at will.
